description: From Anglo-Norman outrageus, Middle French outrageus, from outrage; equivalent to outrage +â€Ž -ous.

adjectives.description: outrageous (comparative more outrageous, superlative most outrageous)

entries.meaning: Violating morality or decency; provoking indignation or affront. [from 14th c.]
examples: The Irish-French rugby union whistler Alain Rolland was roundly condemned for his outrageous decision that lifting a player into the air then turning him over so he falls on his head or neck amounted to dangerous play.

entries.meaning: Transgressing reasonable limits; extravagant, immoderate. [from 14th c.]
examples: Audience members praised McKellen, best known for Shakespearean roles and as Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings, for his show-stealing turn as Twankey in a series of outrageous glitzy dresses.

entries.meaning: Shocking; exceeding conventional behaviour; provocative. [from 18th c.]
examples: "It's something I really am quite nervous about," he admits, before adding, with relish: "You have to be a bit outrageous and challenging sometimes."
